result.markdown:
---
title: "ANOVA"
format: html
editor: visual
message: false
warning: false
---


# Bibliotecas


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(gsheet)
library(patchwork)
```
:::


# Importa dados


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
soja <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=866852711")
soja <- soja |> 
  mutate(TRAT = as.factor(TRAT),
         BLOCO = as.factor(BLOCO))
```
:::


# Visualiza dados


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
dfc <- soja |> 
  ggplot(aes(TRAT, DFC))+
  geom_jitter(width = 0.05, color = "gray70")+
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_cl_boot", size = 0.5, color = "black",
               alpha = 0.5)


fer <- soja |> 
  ggplot(aes(TRAT, FER))+
  geom_jitter(width = 0.05, color = "gray70")+
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_cl_boot", size = 0.5, color = "black",
               alpha = 0.5)

prod <- soja |> 
  ggplot(aes(TRAT, PROD))+
  geom_jitter(width = 0.05, color = "gray70")+
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_cl_boot", size = 0.5, color = "black",
               alpha = 0.5)

# mean_cl_boot : intervalo de confiança
# stat_summary: calcula o valor médio sem precisar usar o sumarize para calcular o valor médio

(dfc + fer + prod)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Anova DFC


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
aov_dfc <- lm(DFC ~ TRAT + BLOCO,
              data = soja)

anova(aov_dfc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: DFC
          Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
TRAT       7 149.299 21.3284 51.5490 8.218e-12 ***
BLOCO      3   0.461  0.1537  0.3716    0.7743    
Residuals 21   8.689  0.4138                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```


:::
:::


Efeito de tratamento foi significativo, de blocos não foi. Vai comparar as médias entre os tratamentos. Mesmo assim, tem que deixar os blocos, porque o delineamento do experimento foi em blocos casualizados. Antes de partir para as comparações múltiplas, tem que verificar as variâncias e homogeneidade.

Checar normalidade e variancias:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(performance)
check_normality(aov_dfc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.978).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(aov_dfc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.532).
```


:::
:::


Todos os pacotes a seguir permitem a comparar as médias dos tratamentos:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(performance)
check_normality(aov_dfc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.978).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(aov_dfc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.532).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(emmeans)
medias_dfc <- emmeans(aov_dfc, ~ TRAT)
medias_dfc
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 TRAT emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL
 1     10.88 0.322 21    10.21    11.54
 2      6.42 0.322 21     5.76     7.09
 3      6.05 0.322 21     5.38     6.72
 4      4.75 0.322 21     4.08     5.42
 5      4.20 0.322 21     3.53     4.87
 6      4.00 0.322 21     3.33     4.67
 7      4.08 0.322 21     3.41     4.74
 8      4.58 0.322 21     3.91     5.24

Results are averaged over the levels of: BLOCO 
Confidence level used: 0.95 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pwpm(medias_dfc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
        1       2       3       4       5       6       7       8
1 [10.87]  <.0001  <.0001  <.0001  <.0001  <.0001  <.0001  <.0001
2   4.450 [ 6.42]  0.9896  0.0249  0.0017  0.0006  0.0009  0.0107
3   4.825   0.375 [ 6.05]  0.1329  0.0107  0.0040  0.0058  0.0628
4   6.125   1.675   1.300 [ 4.75]  0.9202  0.7173  0.8072  0.9999
5   6.675   2.225   1.850   0.550 [ 4.20]  0.9998  1.0000  0.9896
6   6.875   2.425   2.050   0.750   0.200 [ 4.00]  1.0000  0.9020
7   6.800   2.350   1.975   0.675   0.125  -0.075 [ 4.07]  0.9499
8   6.300   1.850   1.475   0.175  -0.375  -0.575  -0.500 [ 4.57]

Row and column labels: TRAT
Upper triangle: P values   adjust = "tukey"
Diagonal: [Estimates] (emmean) 
Lower triangle: Comparisons (estimate)   earlier vs. later
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(multcomp)
cld(medias_dfc, Letters = LETTERS)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 TRAT emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 6      4.00 0.322 21     3.33     4.67  A    
 7      4.08 0.322 21     3.41     4.74  A    
 5      4.20 0.322 21     3.53     4.87  A    
 8      4.58 0.322 21     3.91     5.24  AB   
 4      4.75 0.322 21     4.08     5.42  AB   
 3      6.05 0.322 21     5.38     6.72   BC  
 2      6.42 0.322 21     5.76     7.09    C  
 1     10.88 0.322 21    10.21    11.54     D 

Results are averaged over the levels of: BLOCO 
Confidence level used: 0.95 
P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 8 estimates 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05 
NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol,
      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```


:::
:::


## Anova FER


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
aov_fer <- lm(FER ~ TRAT + BLOCO,
              data = soja)

anova(aov_fer)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: FER
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
TRAT       7 978.87 139.838 55.1717 4.218e-12 ***
BLOCO      3   3.84   1.279  0.5045    0.6834    
Residuals 21  53.23   2.535                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```


:::
:::


Efeito de tratamento foi significativo, de blocos não foi. Vai comparar as médias entre os tratamentos. Mesmo assim, tem que deixar os blocos, porque o delineamento do experimento foi em blocos casualizados. Antes de partir para as comparações múltiplas, tem que verificar as variâncias e homogeneidade.

Checar normalidade e variancias:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(aov_fer)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Warning: Non-normality of residuals detected (p = 0.008).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(aov_fer)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Warning: Heteroscedasticity (non-constant error variance) detected (p < .001).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(DHARMa)
plot(simulateResiduals(aov_fer)) #melhorou ainda mais a normmalidade e não atendeu a heterocedasticidade
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Não foi verificado homogeneidade e foi verificado heterocedasticidade entre as variâncias, então não pode continuar com a ANOVA.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Transformação dos dados por log
aov_fer2 <- lm(log(FER) ~ TRAT + BLOCO,
              data = soja)

anova(aov_fer2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: log(FER)
          Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
TRAT       7 11.5210 1.64585 42.9665 4.838e-11 ***
BLOCO      3  0.2064 0.06880  1.7961    0.1788    
Residuals 21  0.8044 0.03831                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(aov_fer2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.255).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(aov_fer2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Warning: Heteroscedasticity (non-constant error variance) detected (p = 0.035).
```


:::
:::


Como o heterocedasticidade de 0,035, vamos considerar que não foi uma violação tão grave (num alfa de 0,05) e vamos seguir com a transformação

Todos os pacotes a seguir permitem a comparar as médias dos tratamentos:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(emmeans)
medias_fer <- emmeans(aov_fer, ~ TRAT)
medias_fer
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 TRAT emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL
 1     20.25 0.796 21    18.59    21.91
 2      5.88 0.796 21     4.22     7.53
 3      4.00 0.796 21     2.34     5.66
 4      3.12 0.796 21     1.47     4.78
 5      3.25 0.796 21     1.59     4.91
 6      3.00 0.796 21     1.34     4.66
 7      3.38 0.796 21     1.72     5.03
 8      3.50 0.796 21     1.84     5.16

Results are averaged over the levels of: BLOCO 
Confidence level used: 0.95 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pwpm(medias_fer)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


:::

```{.r .cell-code}

cld(medias_fer, Letters = LETTERS)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 TRAT emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 6      3.00 0.796 21     1.34     4.66  A    
 4      3.12 0.796 21     1.47     4.78  A    
 5      3.25 0.796 21     1.59     4.91  A    
 7      3.38 0.796 21     1.72     5.03  A

P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 8 estimates 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05

      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```


:::
:::


Utilizando o boxcox (variável transformada:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(MASS)
b <- boxcox(lm(soja$FER+0.1 ~1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
lambda <- b$x[which.max(b$y)]

#Usando o lambda na fórmula: y(lambda) = (x^lambda -1)/lambda
soja$FER3 <- (soja$FER ^ lambda - 1) / lambda

aov_FER3 <- lm(FER3 ~ TRAT + BLOCO,
         data = soja)

anova(aov_FER3)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: FER3
          Df   Sum Sq   Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
TRAT       7 0.036632 0.0052332 12.5567 3.033e-06 ***
BLOCO      3 0.005360 0.0017865  4.2867    0.0165 *  
Residuals 21 0.008752 0.0004168                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(aov_FER3)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.790).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(aov_FER3)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.834).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
medias_fer3 <- emmeans(aov_FER3, ~ TRAT)
medias_fer3
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


## Anova PROD


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
aov_prod <- lm(PROD ~ TRAT + BLOCO,
              data = soja)

anova(aov_prod)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: PROD
          Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)  
TRAT       7 2993906  427701  2.6367 0.04021 *
BLOCO      3  105665   35222  0.2171 0.88340  
Residuals 21 3406431  162211                  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```


:::
:::


Efeito de tratamento foi significativo, de blocos não foi. Vai comparar as médias entre os tratamentos. Mesmo assim, tem que deixar os blocos, porque o delineamento do experimento foi em blocos casualizados. Antes de partir para as comparações múltiplas, tem que verificar as variâncias e homogeneidade.

Checar normalidade e variancias:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(aov_prod)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.542).
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(aov_prod)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.215).
```


:::
:::


Todos os pacotes a seguir permitem a comparar as médias dos tratamentos:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}

medias_prod
```

# Apresentação dos dados?

Pode ser um gráfico para cada um das variáveis (prod, fer e dfc), ou fazer uma tabela, que apresenta essas informações (cada em uma coluna).

PRODUTIVIDADE:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df_prod <- data.frame(medias_prod)

df_prod |> 
  ggplot(aes(TRAT, emmean))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_errorbar(aes(min = lower.CL,
                    max = upper.CL),
                width = 0.1)+
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 1.2, y = 4200, label = "A")+
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 8.2, y = 5100, label = "B")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
df_prod <- cld(medias_prod, Letters = LETTERS)
df_prod <- as.data.frame(df_prod)


knitr::kable(df_prod |> dplyr::select(TRAT, emmean, .group))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|   |TRAT |  emmean|.group |
|:--|:----|-------:|:------|
|1  |1    | 4219.25|A      |
|2  |2    | 4935.00|AB     |
|8  |8    | 5078.25|AB     |
|3  |3    | 5110.00|AB     |
|5  |5    | 5122.00|AB     |
|7  |7    | 5127.50|AB     |
|4  |4    | 5140.25|AB     |
|6  |6    | 5256.25|B      |


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(writexl)
write_xlsx(df_prod, "df.xlsx")
```
:::


# Importação dos dados


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
curve <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=1807247585")
```
:::


# Visualiza dados


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
curve |> 
  ggplot(aes(day, severity))+
  geom_jitter()+
  facet_wrap(~~Irrigation)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
curve |> 
  group_by(day, Irrigation) |> 
  summarise(mean_sev = mean(severity)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(day, mean_sev))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_line()+
  facet_wrap(~~ Irrigation)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
curve |> 
  group_by(day, Irrigation) |> 
  summarise(mean_sev = mean(severity)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(day, mean_sev, color = Irrigation))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_line()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula8_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-3.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(epifitter)
curve2 <- curve |> 
  group_by(Irrigation, rep) |> 
  summarise(aacpd = AUDPC(day, severity))
```
:::


Pode fazer a anova para a AUCPD (integração das obsevações (severidade) ao longo do tempo)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
m_curve <- lm(aacpd ~ Irrigation + factor(rep), data = curve2)

anova(m_curve)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: aacpd
            Df  Sum Sq  Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)  
Irrigation   1 0.23602 0.236017  10.605 0.08275 .
factor(rep)  2 0.61291 0.306454  13.771 0.06770 .
Residuals    2 0.04451 0.022254                  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(agricolae)
cv.model(m_curve) #coeficiente de variação
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1.097572
```


:::
:::


Eficácia é uma razão entre dois valores, severidade ou AUCPD sobre a sev ou AUCPD máxima (do testemunha) - 1 (pq 1 = a doença total) \*100 (pra dar em porcentagem)
